Comment: There's a few ways to answer this, but the short answer is "no"   First, there are state-level parties that are not called the Democratic Party. Example   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minnesota_Democratic%E2%80%93Farmer%E2%80%93Labor_Party   Second, parties can and do break up. See the Libertarians in 2022   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_Party_USA   But finally, political parties don't have the degree of control you seem to think they do   The Pennsylvania Democratic Party is made up of State Committee Members and individual County Committees. The County Committees are make up of individual Precinct Committee Members   If members of the State or County leadership chose to join a different political party, they wouldn't dissolve their existing roles, they would vacate them, and the vacancies would be filled. And most Committee Members would - correctly - see such a move as nothing but a power play and tell the ex-Dems to go piss up a rope if they demanded the Committee Members now affiliate with them.   The new party would need to basically start from scratch from an organization perspective
